I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  2013  country  programming  mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested that the Asian Development Bank (ADB) provide a policy 
and advisory technical assistance (TA) project to respond to policy and capacity building needs 
in priority areas of the 12th Five-Year Plan, 2011–2015 and 13th Five-Year Plan, 2016–2020. In 
response to the request, ADB included a TA project in the 2014 nonlending program. A fact-
finding mission was fielded in August 2014 and an agreement was reached with the executing 
agency,  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF),  on  TA  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements, cost and financing plan, and outline terms of reference (TOR). 1 The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  After  30  years  of  rapid  growth,  the  PRC  has  become  the  world's  second-largest 
economy. However, as reforms continue, the country needs to find new engines for growth. 
With rising wages, a now declining labor force, and an aging population, growth will have to be 
increasingly  driven  by  productivity  gains.  Moreover,  rapid  growth  has  created  structural 
problems that need to be addressed, including economic imbalances, unbalanced rural and 
urban development, resource constraints, environmental degradation, and income inequality. 
These  problems  have  been  accompanied  by  incomplete  reforms  and  limited  capacity  and 
institutional development.  
 
3.  To encourage sustainable development, the Third Plenum of the 18th National Congress 
of  the  PRC’s  Communist  Party  announced  its  “Decision  on  Major  Issues  Regarding 
Comprehensively Deepening Reform” in November 2013. The decisions provide a blueprint for 
the PRC’s development in the next decade and beyond, encompassing the 12th and 13th five-
year plans. By 2020, the government aims to have achieved reform results by (i) allowing the 
market to play a decisive role in resource allocation; (ii) enabling the government to function in a 
service-oriented and law-based manner; (iii) building a modern fiscal system that supports 
central  and  local  governments’  initiatives;  (iv)  accelerating  reforms  for  social  security, 
employment,  income  distribution,  education,  and  public  health;  and  (v)  establishing  a 
comprehensive  system  that  protects  the  ecosystem  and  environment.  The  government 
recognizes  the  need  to  tackle  structural  problems  that  constrain  balanced  economic 
development, equality, resources conservation, and ecosystem protection, and has decided to 
address  key  development  issues  by  deepening  reforms  and  accelerating  capacity  building 
progress. 
 
4.  Since  2003,  ADB  has  granted  six  “facility-type”  TA  projects  to  the  PRC  for  the 
government to meet emerging policy advisory and capacity development requirements.2  ADB 
developed the “facility-type” TA modality in partnership with the government as a flexible, quick-
response mechanism where multiple subprojects aligned with the PRC’s priorities and the ADB

strategies are funded under a single TA. The government highly appreciated such TA projects, 
as they helped advance PRC’s reforms and contributed significantly to the implementation of 
the government’s five-year plans. This TA is the seventh “facility-type” TA project financed by 
ADB in the PRC.   
 
5.  According to the evaluation report by the ADB Independent Evaluation Department, 
“facility-type” TA projects have had substantial impact on the development of the government’s 
five-year plans.3 The TA for the Fund for Strategic Policy Conferences and Studies for Poverty 
Reduction contributed to the PRC’s poverty reduction discourse. The TA for the Facility for 
Reform Support and Capacity Building provided policy inputs  to the State Council directives for 
handling  employment  and  entrepreneurship  development  issues  and  contributed  to  the 
establishment  of  the  rural  di-bao  system  nationwide. 4  Some  subprojects’  findings  and 
recommendations have been incorporated into new regulations and law formulations in the PRC.  
The  evaluation  report  recommended  that  ADB  continue  to  work  with  “facility-type”  TA, 
strengthen  the  use  of  ADB  staff  and  international  consultants  for  providing  international 
perspectives, supervisory support, and peer review of locally produced studies.  
 
6.  The objective of the TA is to support the government to deepen policy reforms and 
accelerate  capacity  building  in  areas  prioritized  in  the  PRC’s  reform  agenda.  The  TA  is 
consistent  with  the  strategic  pillar  of  inclusive  and  environmentally  sustainable  growth, 
highlighted  in  ADB’s  PRC  country  partnership  strategy,  2011–2015  and  aligned  with  the 
Midterm Review of Strategy 2020.5 The TA will provide policy recommendations and knowledge 
services to promote the PRC’s inclusive development and environmentally sustainable growth, 
develop government capacities at central and local levels, and increase ADB’s policy impact 
and operational efficiency. The TA will support the implementation of the PRC’s 12th and 13th 
five-year plans and reinforce the PRC–ADB partnership.  
 
III.  THE POLICY AND ADVISORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.   Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact of the TA will be deepened reforms and enhanced government capacities for 
promoting sustainable development. The outcome will be adoption by relevant government 
agencies of policy advice, regulations, new ideas, and best practices that are introduced or 
recommended by the TA to deepen reforms and increase government capacity at central and 
local levels.          
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
8.  The TA will adopt the flexible mechanism effectively employed in previous TA projects to 
undertake strategic interventions in a timely manner. The mechanism allows for joint selection 
                                                
3  Independent Evaluation Department. 2013. Performance Evaluation Report on Facility-Type Technical Assistance 
in the People’s Republic of China. Manila: ADB. The report recommended that ADB continue to work with “facility-
type” TA mode and replicate such engagement in other member countries to increase goodwill for the wider ADB 
country portfolio. 
4  This refers to the system established by the Government of the PRC to cover all rural areas and ensure a minimum 
living standard for the destitute rural poor who lack productive capacities (e.g., childless elderly households, 
disabled individuals, and female-headed households).    
5  ADB. 2012. Country Partnership Strategy: People’s Republic of China, 2011–2015. Manila; and ADB. 2014.

3
and endorsement of new subprojects during TA implementation, which will help meet dynamic 
demands and enable quick responses to the PRC’s emerging development issues.  
 
9.  The TA consists of two parts: component A for policy advice, and component B for 
capacity building. The outputs will include (i) policy synopses and “just-in-time” policy advice, 
and (ii) capacity-building activities.  
 
10.  Component  A  for  policy  advice.  This  component  will  provide  central  and  local 
governments with sound policy advice on priority development issues, including (i) economic 
restructuring;  (ii)  urban  and  rural  integration;  (iii)  resource  conservation  and  environment 
protection;  and  (iv)  social  sector  and  welfare  development.  By  2015,  a  TA  mobilization 
workshop will be organized. During the TA, some bilingual synopses and “just-in-time”advice 
that provide the government with policy recommendations will be produced on selected studies 
relating to the above mentioned four areas. Workshops to disseminate the studies’ main results 
will be conducted to enhance policy impact. A TA wrap-up workshop will be held in 2008.  
 
11.  Component B for capacity building. This component will strengthen the capacity of 
selected central and local government agencies to implement the 12th and 13th five-year plans 
through capacity assessments, training programs, workshops, conferences, and knowledge 
management interventions. Workshops and seminars with participation from government think 
tanks, decision makers, executing and implementing agency representatives, academia, and 
civil society on introducing best practice, knowledge sharing, enhancing PRC–ADB strategic TA 
programming  partnership,  and  training  for  executing  and  implementing  agencies  will  be 
conducted during TA implementation. By TA completion, capacity-building activities will help 
increase the capacities of central and local governments and promote knowledge solutions in 
the PRC.   
 
12.  The subprojects of the TA will be jointly selected and endorsed by the executing agency 
(through the TA Division at MOF) and ADB (through the PRC Resident Mission country director) 
based on mutually agreed selection criteria that will be reviewed during TA implementation. The 
subprojects must (i) support government reform priorities and be consistent with the “Decision 
on Major Issues Regarding Comprehensively Deepening Reform” and the country partnership 
strategy, 2011–2015; (ii) promote the implementation of the 12th and 13th five-year plans; (iii) 
be an urgent and high-priority issue for which ADB has expertise and available capacity to add 
value; and (iv) show evidence of strong PRC ownership.  
 
13.  The  initial  subprojects  identified  under  the  TA  include:  (i)  Qinghai  low-carbon 
development  to  mitigate  climate  change  ($100,000);  (ii)  demonstration  of  integrated 
management of forest and water resources in the Guanting reservoir watershed ($80,000); (iii) 
ecological restoration and protection of abandoned mines—Xiangtan case study ($100,000); (iv) 
study  on  spatial  planning  system  models  ($80,000);  and  (v)  PRC–ADB  strategic  TA 
programming workshop ($80,000). It is expected that MOF and ADB will identify and endorse 
additional subprojects during TA implementation, using the criteria specified in para. 12. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1 million, of which $800,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). A total of $500,000 is 
for component A and $300,000 is for component B. The government will provide counterpart 
support in the form of counterpart staff from the executing and implementing agencies; office 
accommodation; office supplies; data and information; daily coordination; logistics support for

4 
 
missions, meetings and visits for TA implementation; and other in-kind contributions.   
 
15.  Component  A  subprojects  may  also  fund  surveys,  field  investigations,  purchase  of 
required research materials, and other related expenditures on the basis of cost estimates 
agreed in advance by ADB. In line with standard ADB procedures, the TA will not support 
implementing agencies' management fees or costs related to the use of implementing agencies' 
resources to be provided as part of the counterpart contribution. Component B subprojects may 
include  costs  related  to  workshop  venue,  equipment  rental,  translation  and  interpretation, 
material  editing,  copying,  printing  and  dissemination,  food  and  nonalcoholic  beverages, 
transportation, lodging, logistics and administrative support, and other expenditures related to 
TA implementation with prior ADB approval. The ceiling amount for each subproject is $100,000, 
or such other amount as may be mutually agreed by ADB (through the PRC Resident Mission 
country director) and the executing agency (through the TA Division at MOF).   
 
D.   Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  from  1  January  2015  to  31  December  2018.  As  the 
executing  agency,  MOF  (through  its  TA  Division)  will  be  responsible  for  oversight  and 
coordination of subproject activities and TA quality. ADB and MOF will meet periodically to 
review TA progress and update implementation status, with agreements via memorandums of 
understanding to be reached after each meeting. Agreements will include (i) a monitoring table 
updating every component’s implementation status for each TA subproject, (ii) an updated list of 
subprojects involving ongoing and new inclusion, and (iii) a list of action items. A monitoring 
mechanism  will  be  established  by  the  PRC  Resident  Mission  to  track  the  subprojects’ 
implementation status under each component. ADB staff will supervise TA performance in 
cooperation  with  MOF, implementing  agencies,  and  other  relevant  parties.  Frequent  policy 
dialogue  and  communication  will  occur  between  ADB,  MOF,  implementing  agencies,  and 
stakeholders. ADB will evaluate outputs at every milestone and prepare a TA completion report.  
 
17.  Throughout  implementation,  ADB  and  MOF  will  accept  subproject  proposals  from 
government organizations, institutions, and nongovernment organizations. ADB and MOF will 
jointly select subprojects on the basis of the TA design and agreed selection criteria specified in 
para. 12. Training will be provided to familiarize implementing agencies with ADB requirements 
and procedures, and share knowledge, as needed. The PRC Resident Mission will administer 
the TA, with support from the ADB headquarters. During implementation, the PRC Resident 
Mission country director will review and endorse individual proposals for TA inclusion (i.e., 
impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost and financing plan, and specific 
TORs). 
 
18.   ADB will recruit individual consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). A total of 40 person-months of individual 
consulting services (10 person-months of international consultants, and 30 person-months of 
national consultants) will be provided, including resource persons and task-specific experts. The 
outline TOR is in Appendix 3. TORs for individual subprojects will be developed in consultation 
with  relevant  implementing  agencies  and  ADB’s  Operations  Services  and  Financial 
Management Department and approved by the PRC Resident Mission country director, as 
appropriate.  TA  proceeds  will  be  disbursed  in  line  with  ADB's  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). ADB may establish an advance 
payment facility for MOF and the implementing agencies.

5
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Support for Deepening Policy Reform and 
Capacity Building, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  For the technical assistance (TA) to the People's Republic of China (PRC), the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) will recruit an estimated 30 person-months of national consultant 
inputs and 10 person-months of international expert inputs to support research, workshops, and 
other  agreed-upon  subproject  activities.  Consultants,  resource  persons,  and  task-specific 
experts  will  provide  the  inputs  to  introduce  international  best  practices,  provide  in-depth 
knowledge and recommendations, and advise on policy options, challenges, and knowledge 
solutions. The nature of the expertise and inputs will be determined on a case-by-case basis for 
each activity or subproject applied by the implementation agency and jointly endorsed by the 
executing agency (through the TA Division at the Ministry of Finance) and ADB (through the 
PRC Resident Mission country director).  
 
2.  ADB will recruit consultants as individuals in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). 1 The implementing agencies will be 
responsible for proposing terms of reference (TORs) to the Ministry of Finance and ADB for 
consideration. The experts may be independent consultants or recruited from consulting firms, 
research  institutes,  think  tanks,  academic  institutions,  government  research  arms,  or 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs).  
 
A.  Consultants (5 person-months for international, 20 person-months for national) 
 
3.  Indicative tasks of consultants for component 1 (policy advice) subprojects include:  
 
(i)  assisting the executing and implementing agencies and ADB in identifying and/or 
refining the study scope, content, and/or methodology and related activities that 
focus on the PRC’s strategic development issues and are consistent with the  
priority strategies of ADB and the government; 
(ii)  undertaking  research  and  analysis,  as  required  in  the  TORs—international 
experts, in particular, should provide advice and inputs on reform frameworks 
and processes based on international comparative analysis and best practices 
for incorporation into final policy recommendations;  
(iii)  working with the implementing agency and experts to produce study reports 
and/or policy synopsis in the required ADB format to satisfy the TA requirements  
(e.g., policy research studies, assessment reports, policy notes, good practice 
analyses, and related sector and thematic reports); 
(iv)  being responsible for quality control of the final bilingual policy synopses; 
(v)  contributing  to  policy  dialogue  with  and  knowledge  solutions  for  key 
governmental decision-makers, as well as to the TA output dissemination. 
 
4.  Indicative tasks of consultants for component 2 (capacity building) include: 
 
(i)  conducting a detailed human resource and/or institutional needs assessment for 
relevant  government  agencies  and/or  nongovernment  entities,  including 
identifying gaps and obstacles and constraints that limit institutional capacities;

include experience-based methodologies that apply case studies and multiple

(iii)  designing  and  conducting  training-of-trainers  program  to  support  capacity 
building for central and local government officials, executing and implementing 
agencies, NGOs, and other beneficiaries as required; and 
(iv)  contributing inputs to conferences, seminars, workshops, focus group meetings, 
training  sessions,  and  other  events  to  promote  knowledge  sharing  and 
dissemination, and strategic ADB–PRC partnership development. 
 
B.  Task-Specific Experts (2 person-months for international, 5 person-months for 
national) 
 
5.  The task-specific experts selected in accordance with ADB requirements will provide 
technical and/or administrative inputs in their area of expertise to support TA implementation 
and quality control. They will support the executing and implementing agencies in: liaising with 
ADB  and  other  key  stakeholders  to  ensure  effective  policy  dialogues  and  smooth  TA 
implementation; coordinating across agencies and subprojects for implementation; organizing 
workshops  and  knowledge-sharing  events;  reporting  achievements  to  the  executing  and 
implementing agencies and ADB; and contributing inputs to reports and policy synopses, as 
needed. Specific tasks include: 
 
(i)  providing technical and/or administrative inputs based on specific TORs agreed-
upon by the executing agency and/or implementing agencies and ADB;  
(ii)  liaising  with  relevant  stakeholders  for  national  and  internationally  supported 
initiatives  and  ensuring  smooth  communication  and  coordinated  efforts  across 
agencies and organizations and administrative levels; and 
(iii)  updating the executing and implementing agencies and ADB on TA progress and 
assisting them to address implementation and quality control issues.  
 
C.  Resource  Persons  (3  person-months  for  international,  5  person-months  for 
national) 
 
6.  Unless  otherwise  agreed  by  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  and  ADB, 
resource  persons  or  experts  entitled to  receive  honoraria  or  payments to  be  identified  by 
executing and implementing agencies and the ADB include:   
 
(i)  presenters, facilitators, and panels for various workshops and events, including 
conferences,  training  seminars,  and  knowledge  sharing  and  dissemination 
workshops; 
(ii)  representatives  of  various  agencies  (e.g.,  academia,  NGOs,  and  private 
businesses) and other individuals selected by the executing and implementing 
agencies and/or ADB to (a) act as discussants on related policy issues; (b) present 
fact findings, research results, and policy suggestions; and (c) review and refine 
policy synopses/reports and/or comment on selected research; and  
(iii)  researchers and leading experts commissioned by the implementing agencies to 
prepare studies on topics or provide “just-in-time” policy advice that are agreed by 
the executing and implementing agencies and ADB to help achieve TA results.
